review_blob: Can.  Reddish-golden hue with limited head.  tangerine, hoppy to the nose.  Citrusy and somewhat suprisingly flavorful; has the chops to compete straight up vs. Bells Hopslam for my affections, though kind of like the trailer park version.  Impressive and clearly worth putting in regular rotation.  This is the definition of the perfect lawn mower beer.

Bottle.  Deep maroon brown color.  No head.  Clear.  Caramel, toffee, malty.  Noticeable hops.  Rich in flavor and aroma, bitter rye aftertaste lingers long.  Warm alcohol numbness.  2 part flavoring with confusing dissonance on tongue and nose.
Bottle.  Caramel brown coloring.  No head.  Thin in consistency.  yeasty, hoppy, doughy.  Smooth delivery.  Understated at first but emerges with bready finish.  acidic on tongue.  Yep.

Bottle.  "Light does not pass through this," says Lise.  Black opaque color.  Virtually no head.  Coffee, roasted notes, nuts, spicy . . . like a hidden nutmeg.  Caramel, toffee hints as well.  Malty bitterness blend on front of the tongue to start followed by a toffee coffee finish.  Well balanced.  Neither too heavy nor too light.  Solid

Bottle.  Brown sugar brown red color.  Hazy and clumpy.  Uber-malty, apple hints, vanilla, cherries.  Deceptive.  I expected a sugar flavoring but instead got more subtle sweet/sharp play off one another from the initial flavoring and a creamy vanilla and lavender finish.  Nice.  Tricky.

Bottle.  Opaque black color.  No head.  Grapes, dates, mocha, licorice.  Medium to thicker body.  Extraordinary choclate and cherry combo.  Motor-oil thick, sugary, pleasing finish.

Ive been waiting for you and you did not disappoint.

Bottle.  Tomato juice dark red coloring.  No head.  Cherry mash.  Yeasty.  Cheek-puckering sour.  More malty and flavorful than I expected given the aroma.  Average body and sustaining sour, bitter, fruity finish.  Unbelievably nice.
Draft.  battery-acid copper coloring.  Interesting hops aroma.  musty, honey, syrupy, barley.  Bitter.  Eh, no.
beer_name: Blue & Gray Falmouth American Pale Ale

review_blob: Bottle.  Bronze color.  Clear.  Static, no head to speak of.  Pinot-noir, wine-like initial aroma.  wooden, hoppy, hints of butter, citrus, rose, sweet.  Quite nice and a good pickup where you can find it.

Bottle.  Opaque black color.  No head, though tannish ring circles the glass.  Roasted elements, malty, coffee beans, almonds, nutty.  Soda-like in consistency, though watery and flat.  Bland and weak past the aroma and a real disappointment.  Dont tease the drinker.

Bottle.  Lemon coloring.  Clear.  1/2" head with visible and active carbonation.  Noticeably citrusy in aroma, like a pungent graprefruit.  Tangy and hoppy to the tongue that gives way to fruity notes, esp apricot-like finish.  Medium body and evenly balanced throughout.  Love the kick on top and this is a clear new favorite for me, a rival to Bells Hopslam for my affections.

Bottle.  Brown sugar coloring.  Grassy earthy, vinegar-like.  Musty and a little tart at the initial taste.  Reasonably dry.  Limited residual.  Not my cup of tea but a decent pour and can see many loving it.
Draft.  Brown, root beer bottle coloring.  Flat, no body and the last in my flight.  Earns my scorn.

Draft.  Lemon color, hazy.  fruity-light.  Pleasing.  Im getting tired of this flight of beers and this one is scarily standing out as the best of GB.  Probably inflating my ratings as a true beer goggle kicks in.
Draft.  Cherry pine color.  Light red hue.  brown sugar.  2 part flavoring w/ heavy wooden ring in the back of the throat.  not a great finish or beer.
Draft.  Pale brown.  clear, thin in appearance and body.  Chili hints; distinctly spicy.  nice even blend of malt, hops, spices.  Solid, even if unimpressive.

Bottle.  Toffee-caramel color.  Cider like, sugary, hoppy.  Sweet and notably pumpkin-y, if that can be a ord.  Candy, apple, and toffee notes present too.  Enjoyed a residual malty sweetness on the tongue.  The high and increasingly higher ABV is evident from the start on roof of mouth.  Aromatic and nice full body.  In your face kind of beer; theres no kiesch eaters drinking this.

Amber color.  1" head.  Pungent blueberry aroma.  "Did someone just club me with a 20 pound blueberry?"  Must have knocked me silly, b/c I couldnt taste much at all after the aroma.  Somewhat empty citrus flavoring, a little tart.  1-note wonder that abandons all other facets of a good beer as most fruity beers do.

Draft.  Scotch borwn color.  Surface head.  Nutty, malty, almost a turpentine hint that hits the nostrils.  Thats not good for those listening at home.  Oak, wooden.  Ok for a brown but was hoping for better.  These guys have a very nice deck and view of Richmond skyline.  that adds to appeal of the beer.
Draft.  Cloudy, hazy battery acid brown in color.  Light head.  Clearly hoppy from the jump.  Citrusy fruit hints, not too bitter.  Flat, flavor muted and watery.  Ok

Draft.  Frosty, lemon copper color.  Frothy 1 1/2" head with slow dissipation.  Hoppy, butter, light hint of bread, grains.  Watery delivery slides off tongue, like the flavoring is running away.  Boo, I say.  Boo.

Draft.  Grapefruit hazy color.  overly citrusy lemon in flavoring and similar in taste.  No body or depth to speak of.  What was that I was drinking?  Dont remember except its 12 ounces of a better beer I could have been drinking.

Bottle.  Caramel brown color.  2 inch lacey, lucious head.  Apricot, orange, tangy hints.  Hoppy in aroma and taste; gives me that good citrus bitterness I crave in an IPA.  Exquisite mix of hops, fruit, toffee.  Like drinkinga Jolly Rancher candy.  Very nice and worth searching for.

Bottle.  Golden coloring.  1 1/2" head.  Hazy, cloudy, yeasty, wheaty, grainy, any more similar adjectives to add?  Dry.  Not bitter.  I like it in spots but generally speaking am not an admirer here.  Eh.

Bottle.  Maroon red translucent coloring.  No head.  Like melted candle wax.  Tea, dates / dark fruit.  Swear I catch an odd whiff of dijon mustard too.  Warm and disarming on initial tasting.  A little sharp, acidic to tongue and roof of mouth, following by a tea flavored finish.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Bottle.  Deep brown molasses.  Smooth pour with tannish head.  Mocha chocolate, doughy and sugary.  Need a fire to roast this beer with my marshmellows

Bottle.  Caramel molasses brown color.  Ample 1 1/2" head.  Lightly lacey.  Brown sugar, raisin, nutty, malty.  Much more sedate in flavoring and finish than aroma foretold.  Like prude who comes off slutty in the beginning.  Marshmellow, dry, hoppy.  nice finish

beer_brewer_name: Bar Harbor Brewing Company (Atlantic Brewing Company)
review_blob: Bottle.  Brownish maroon color. Limited, ringed head.  Caramel, nutty and malty.  Regrettably flat flavoring; no bite but also nothing particularly distinctive or memorable.  Limps to the finish.  Wouldnt refuse if offered but wouldnt go out of my way to find either.

Bottle.  Thin, black opaque coloring.  No head to speak of.  Coffee, roasted notes, banana.  Cherry hint - fruity but hard to place.  Even delivery with heavy burnt-toast coffee ground ending.  solid.

Bottle.  Copper coloring.  Quick dissipation of 1/2" head.  Active carbonation from  bottom.  Translucent.  Wooden, earthy, almost metallic in aroma.  Light in body and limited flavoring.  Hints of honey; corn-like in finish.

Bottle.  Caramel color.  Light rimmed head.  Chocolate, banana, malty.  roasted notes.  Smooth and sweet; not bitter or tart as I would have expected.  A little watery and thin in body.  Left a green tea residual on its way down.  ok.

beer_brewer_name: Port Brewing Co / The Lost Abbey
review_blob: Bottle. Deep black color.  Tannish ringed head.  Licorice, malty.  Roasty but not overdone.  Dates / raisin hints.  Thin, slightly watery in body and taste.  1-part flavoring with nothing distinctive on exhale or finish.  Hoped for better given what these guys normally do but this is a relative disappointment
beer_name: Port Brewing Midnight Expression Lager (Moon Lit Sessions)

review_blob: Bottle.  inviting black color with tannish beige head.  Soda-like in consistency and appearance.  Coffee grounds, vanilla, decaf-black like my mother used to drink.  Smooth with lightly acidic finish.  Very drinkable.  I have a bias for Bells - I come in expecting a good pour every time.

Bottle.  Translucent yellow-urine coloring. No head. Juice-like.  Yeasty, lavender, spicy.  Assaults the nose, especially the peppery-coriander mix.  Flavoring is much more delicate and not as in your face as the aroma.  Best served semi-warm.  Im a fan.

Bottle.  Lemon, light color with limited but soapy head that hangs on the glass.  Wheaty, citrusy, grainy.  Average to light body.  Somewhat bready on the finish.  A nice beverage when seeking something on the lighter side but still with enough flavoring to be distinctive

Bottle.  Pale, faint grapefruit/lemon color.  No head.  Lightly hazy and moderate carbonation.  Yeasty, citrusy, lemon, lime.  Doughy and spicy to the taste.  Tangy with some bitterness on tongue at finish.

Bottle.   Black, motor oil coloring.  Consistency and appearance of soda/cola.  No head to speak of.  Vanilla, malty, white whine, clear hints of whiskey blend all together.  Extraordinarily smooth flavoring.  Thin consistency for a RIS but not at all lacking in character.  Somewhat flat; I suspect the seal wasnt tight enough.  Nicely done, though didnt blow me away.
beer_name: Pennichuck Pozharnik Espresso Russian Imperial Stout

review_blob: Bottle.  Lemon, urine-brown color.  Ample 2"  sudsy head with slow dissipation.  Clear.  Wheaty, grainy, hops noticeable and pleasing in aroma.  Smooth and even in flavoring, neither tart, tangy, or bitter.  Medium body - definitely not heavy.  Exhale is a sweet, fruity goodbye.  Nice.
Draft.  Deep, black cola molasses.  No head.  Coffee grounds, malty.  Thin, black coffee flavoring with some roasted notes poking through an otherwise unimpressive offering

Draft.  Grapefruit brown color.  Light, soapy head.  Lemony and spicy, chili powder, coriander.  Flat flavoring.  Thin body but pleasing.  Doughy in residual. 
OK

Draft.  Clear golden lemon.  no carbonation, limited head.  Lightly wheaty, grainy, a refined Bud Light, really.  Distinctive corn in aroma and barley, hoppy flavoring in taste, giving it a little kick and wake me up in an other wise listless beginning.
Draft.  Copper color.  Light ringed head. No carbonation.  Faintly hoppy, corn flavoring.  Eh.

Draft.  Frosty, lemon copper color.  Frothy, 1 1/2" head with slow dissipation.  Hoppy, butter, light hint of grain, bread.  Watery delivery that slides off the tongue, like the flavor is running away.  Boo.
Draft.  Marron dark brownish color.  No head.  No activity.  Root beer candy, brown sugar aroma.  Nice flavoring, nutty, sweet, though no real finish.  Drinkable.
Bottle.  Hazy, grapefruit lemon color with 1/2" head.  Lemon, wheaty, grainy, cloves.  Listless initial delivery, thin body, but steadily comes on strong with spicy, wheaty finish.  Ok

Bottle.  Soda like coloring and consistency in appearance.  Active carbonation with brownish white hue on surface.  malty, chocolate, hint of egg (oddly).  Very thin in body and watery to the tongue.  Strained coffee ground finish gives it a little kick but far less than a solid punch.  Eh.

Bottle.  Dark molasses black body with maroon orange hue.  Limited head, no lace.  Chocolate, coffee grounds, roasted malts, mild vanilla.  Smooth, even body, not bitter or carbonated, nor heavy as some porter overwhelm you with their "robustness".  Fudge, malty initial flavoring gives way to coffee bitterness that lingers a little longer in the mouth and on the tongue than Id prefer.  Distinctive and drinkable.  Solid offering from Smuttynose, whom I ordinarily do not prefer.
Bottle.  Deep amber, oak coloring.  Limited head.  Toffee, brown sugar, malty mix.  Thin body, somewhat sour and bitter in flavoring and finish.  Ok but not memorable or impressive.
beer_name: Casco Bay Winter Ale (Old Port Ale)

review_blob: Bottle.  Deep black maroon color.  No head.  thick, molasses pour, almost unbelievably thick.  Chocolate, fudge, nutty hints.  Smooth delivery.  Distinctly malty but not overbearing.  Pinot noir, grape notes present.  Excellent choice.  Special thanks to Dennis Gilligan for this find.

Bottle.  Opaque, black motor oil coloring.  No head.  Grapes, pinot noir hints, tart.  Flavorful explosion.  Malty, sweet, floral notes.  Complexity obvious as is the high alcohol exhale (I could light my breath with a lighter).  Overpowering and worth every drop.
